Posts.Content: I suffered from nausea a lot in the beginning. Until I changed my food intake. With xeloda I simply need more carbohydrates. With "healthy" food I suffer from nausea unless I add bread or potatoe or rice but best of sll: cookies...
Posts.Title: How do you handle side effects from Xeloda?

Posts.Content: "I have two kids and a grandson that means the world to me, I will Never Give up and will fight this terrible disease", you wrote. Part of this struggle is how to get yourself out of the obsessive fear. There are techniques such as counseling, meditation or yoga and all of them can be really good. But I want to share with you somethig simple that helped me again and again: daily walks in a pleasant environment. It really makes me feel so much better adwith my feet on the ground. But from time to time this isn't enough.I have then to "look the beast in the eye". I tell myself: Okay, I will die. What would I want to say before to the ones I love. What would I want to do still if my death was near. In my mind I then prepare for it. This has on me a calming effect. When I am "prepared" I can turn again in the other direction, fighting the disease by healthy living, being involved in tasks (preferably being active with something meaningfull), AND... spoiling myself and enjoying good moments to the full. With your latest diagnosis you are right now still in shock. But when your new treatment will be in place I am sure you will find out what works with you. Prayers, mantras, a boxing ball or whatever... ;)
Posts.Title: Depressed...tnbc

Posts.Content: Thank you for giving us not just the sad news but a loving portret. Your holding her hand and remaining without her has touched me deeply.
Posts.Title: In Memoriam, "New Challenges"

Posts.Content: I have pleural effusion since 2006. It was then that I was declred stage-4. At the time I was drained Since then I live with 1/3 lung malfunctioning but not deteriorating. Mets did spread to bones and liver. Did all the hormonal treatments and now 2 years on Xeloda. I actually don't feel bad. Just more tired since on chemo (xeloda). Initially suffered from its SE, but after lowered dosage and eating more carbs can live with it.
Posts.Title: MBC Mets to the Pleura

Posts.Content: "Don't walk away - RUN!" - that's one to remember. Addition to your list: As somebody who did speak about my MBC diagnosis, it happened that years later I encounteted someone who apparently was shocked to see me. "You said you had cancer!" She just didn't add explicitly "You should be dead by now". Another thing making me a pretender in the eyes of some: I am telling that I am now undergoing chemo treatment. But with Xeloda I still have my hair... Still, I'm not willing to tell less than the truth when asked how and what. Avoiding to say it as it is may be more polite but would leave me more sombre.
Posts.Title: Shocking Things People Say To Breast Cancer Patients and How I Coped

Posts.Content: Wonderful news. Yes, we are each others lifeline, exchanging experience and spirit. Now your good news lifts my spirit which needed some, because of feeling so much weaker in the summer heat which only now began but will stay on for months. Not a good combination with xeloda side effects. But... perhaps I will gradually adjust and have also better days.
Posts.Title: Thank You Inspire Friends for Helping Me Get To This Point!

Posts.Content: Mbcbone, I agree with you. That professor of Radiology spoke about statistical probability. But what I learned from statistics is that there is always also room for exceptions. Since mets to my lung arra were found in 2006 I live on the hope to be an exception. My intuition told me to gamble that my cancer is not one of the most aggressive and I have in those 13 years been insisting on first trying mild therapies and/or low doses. Avoiding overmedication is one way to live longer. I have not been NED ever after the mbc diagnosis. But I am under the impression that stability is what counts the most. If that can be had with NED - fine. But it is okay with me to have in my body "sleeping" tumors, as long as I can function. Why sacrificing the healthy part of me to get totally rid of those sleeping mets? Preserving the healthy part of body and mind is also important for survival.Therefore, I believe in staying active but avoiding stress, doing enough enjoyable things; and also: daily walks, eating wisely, adding supplements. You cannot leave it only to the doctors.
Posts.Title: Stage 4 long survival

Posts.Content: You have a wonderful family, you say. Probably you not only need them but they do need you too. Me it helps to know that I can still mean something to others. Doing little things for others also keeps you active. Filling each day with some activity - for yourself or others, alone or together - is very important.
Posts.Title: Depression and breast cancer

Posts.Content: ...and you are a wonderful daughter, "keeping it under your hat". But with the close bond you two had and have she knows it intuitively anyway. If you don't want to speak about it you can hold her hand and think of it all in togetherness.
Posts.Title: Dealing with a Parent with Dementia and Stage IV Breast Cancer In Child

Posts.Content: Dear Yechi Of course you are disappointed, but this seems to be "only" a set back, not more. My guess: your doctor wants to try another not so different medicine (the trial med, whatever it is) and not already escalating to chemo. I myself am since 2 years on xeloda (chemo pills) and even that is not yet doomsday... I have mets all over the place but not near the original tumor. However I would think it's not the worst place where progression could show up... Telling myself with every bad result: I hope still to get very often bad results...
Posts.Title: Anyone experience progression in breast

Posts.Content: Complete healing - that's not for us in this stage-4 forum. Surviving as long as possible with it, and learning to live reasonably well with side effects is what we hope for. But perhaps you are in a better situation. What stage is your BC? If this growth near the place of origin is your first metastase you would have a far better prognosis, however difficult emotionally to be torn between hope and fear.
Posts.Title: Anyone experience progression in breast

Posts.Content: Maybe you can while waiting for July do something about it on your own. Assuming the worst you could start taking i3c pills which are sold as supplement over the counter. They give what eating huge amounts of broccoli would give. For me it worked a whole year as well as the hormonal meds which kept me stable all of them together 11 years. (I am since doing well on chemo pills.) You can read about it in the link. IF it is true what you fear and you do have metastased BC to the bones it would have a chance to be helpful. There was recently also an article about it in the NYT. https://www.mskcc.org/cancer-care/integrative-medicine/herbs/ind... By the way, your feeling pain all over - is it always same spots or now here than there? Aching bone mets are in my experience very locally fixed and don't show up now here then there...
Posts.Title: Numb chin

Posts.Content: You ask about our experience. Well, mine is not with your symptomls, but still maybe relevant. You should indeed see a neurologist as you apparently planned already. But patallel to that you need to work on getting rid of the stress. Stress is unpleasant and not healthy either. It could easily make other symptoms worse. Maybe you should seek advice for that and find what suits you. There is of course acupuncture and yoga etc. But you could also see a councillor. All this NOT instead of seeking physical checks, but in addition. Your kids should have a mother who is not stressed all the time. And more important you yourself have the right to be supported in order to deal with the facts of life without complicating them by unhelpful stressing. And ... don't forget to spoil yourself from time to time. An evening with a friend can cheer you up. Also, a walk in a beautiful park. Or buying that book or that dress which is a bit expensive. You deserve something extra. Edited May 21, 2019 at 3:06 pm
Posts.Title: Numb chin

Posts.Content: Dear LalaM. A secundary breastcancer in the lung is another way of saying "your breastcancer has spread to the lung" or "there is a metastasis in the lung". https://www.cancer.gov/publications/dictionaries/cancer-terms/de... All of us here in the BC stage-4 group have secundary cancers. In my case the first mets were found on the pleura, causing accumulation of water around lung leading to breathing problems, 13 years ago... (This is to tell you "don't believe the statistics - beat them".)
Posts.Title: anyone with a secondary breast cancer in lungs ?

Posts.Content: No, I didn't even try to do a trial. The trial has demands on you - many blood tests and scans. It is not organized for the participants but for a more abstract cause. I declined it out of laziness. But wanted to tell you CONGRATS that you have it only in bones. That is very unpleasant but so much less dangerous tha when it gets to vital organs... the half full glass ;) Edited May 21, 2019 at 2:43 pm
Posts.Title: No clinical trial

Posts.Content: Can you not ask your general practioner to arrange for you an earlier appointment with the neurologist? You could explicitly tell him/her that you are worried it may be numb chin syndrom and connected with the breast problem. I can't believe that a GP would then not have the option of arranging a more urgent appointment. Where I live (Israel) this would be possible. I hope you will succeed, too.
Posts.Title: Numb chin

Posts.Content: I have it already for a long time. Apart from hot tea and water, also sucking a (sugar free) ricola pastille is helpful.
Posts.Title: Coughing
